revisions.rev:
{{Infobox National football team | Name = England Under-17 | Flag = Flag of England.svg | Badge = England crest 2009.svg | FIFA Trigramme = ENG | Nickname = Three Lions | Association = [[The Football Association]] | Confederation = [[UEFA]] (Europe) | Coach = {{flagicon|ENG}} [[John Peacock (footballer born 1956)|John Peacock]] | pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= _eng11h|pattern_ra1= |pattern_so1= _englandh2010 | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=003399|socks1=FFFFFF | pattern_la2= |pattern_b2= _englanda2011|pattern_ra2= |pattern_sh2= |pattern_so2= _englanda2011| | leftarm2=1E1E1E|body2=1E1E1E|rightarm2=1E1E1E|shorts2=6DACDF|socks2=1E1E1E | First game = | Largest win = | Largest loss = | Most Recent match = | World cup apps = | World cup first = | World cup best = | Regional name = [[UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|European Championship]] | Regional cup apps = ? | Regional cup first = 1984 | Regional cup best = Winners: [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2010]] }} The '''England national under-17 football team''', also known as [[England]] under-17s or England U17(s), represents [[England]] in [[association football]] at a under-17 age level and is controlled by [[the Football Association]], the governing body for [[football in England]]. The current manager is [[John Peacock (footballer born 1956)|John Peacock]]. ==John Peacock== John Peacock has been with the FA since 2002. He specialises in youth development and coach education and is the FA's Head of Coaching. He holds the FA Academy Directors Licence and [[UEFA Pro Licence]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U17s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2002/07/17321|title=John Peacock profile|date=16 May 2006|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2009-03-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Competition history== ===UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship=== The England under-17 team compete in the annual [[UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]]. In 1984 they finished in third beating [[Serbia national football team]] 1-0 in the third place match. England were the hosts of the [[2001 UEFA European Under-16 Football Championship|2001]] Final Tournament, with the English reaching the semi-finals where they lost 4-0 to [[France national football team|France]] on 3 May. They finished fourth, losing the third place play off match 4-1 to [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]]. They finished third in [[2002 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2002]] in [[Denmark]] and fourth again in [[2003 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2003]] in [[Portugal]] and [[2004 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2004]] in [[France]]. The [[2007 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2007]] tournament saw England finish as runners-up in [[Belgium]]. In the final, held at the [[R.F.C. Tournai|Stade Luc Varenne]] in [[Tournai]], they lost 1-0 to [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] on 13 May. In [[2008 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship elite round|2008]], they failed to qualify for the finals. They reached the final tournament in [[2009 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2009]], but finished bottom of their group. In [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2010]] the England under-17 team fared much better in the group stages, winning Group B with maximum points - ahead of [[Turkey national youth football team|Turkey]], the [[Czech Republic national under-17 football team|Czech Republic]] and [[Greece national under-17 football team|Greece]]. This saw them qualify for the semi-finals of the competition, hosted in [[Liechtenstein]], where they would meet Group A runners-up [[France national under-17 football team|France]]. Thanks to two first half goals by [[Connor Wickham]], England won the game 2-1 and rendered [[Paul Pogba]]'s second half effort a mere consolation. Victory against the French would set up a final with 2007 and 2008 champions [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]], who themselves had beaten Turkey. In the final at the [[Rheinpark Stadion]] the scoring was opened by an Andre Wisdom own goal when the defender deflected a cross by Spain's Gerard into his own net. It took eight minutes for Wisdom to atone for his error, when he headed in on the half hour mark to make the score 1-1. Despite Spain dominating much of the first half, [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town's]] [[Connor Wickham]] scored his third goal of the competition just before the break when the 6'3" striker maneuvered around three Spain defenders and slotted the ball past goalkeeper AdriÃ¡n OrtolÃ¡. England held onto their 2-1 lead in the second half as it proved enough for England under-17 and [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool under-18]] captain Conor Coady to lift the trophy. The victory represents England under-17's first ever UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship title since the annual competition began in 1982. ===Other tournaments=== England have competed in the annual Nordic tournament since the 2002-03 season. In 2004-5, in [[Iceland]], they finished as runners-up to the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]], losing 2-0 in the final in [[ReykjavÃ­k]]. The following season the tournament was held in the [[Faroe Islands]], and England finished as runners-up to the [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]], losing 4-0 in the final in [[Torshavn]]. In 2008, they lost out again to [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] in the final, this time by a 6-1 scoreline. They finally took the title in 2009, beating [[Scotland national under-17 football team|Scotland]] 3-2 in the final. They have competed in the annual Algarve Tournament since 2003-04 season. In 2007-08 they won the tournament.{{cite news|url= http://www.thefa.com/England/U17s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/17sPortugalreport.htm |title=Proud Peacock|date=5 February 2008|publisher=[[The Football Association]]|accessdate=2009-03-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} England host an annual FA international tournament. ==Fixtures & Results 2011â12== ===European Under-17 Championship=== {{main|2012 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship}} ====Qualifying Group 6==== {{main|2012 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship qualifying round#Group 6}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !width=180|Team !width=20|Pld !width=20|W !width=20|D !width=20|L !width=20|GF !width=20|GA !width=20|GD !width=20|Pts |- bgcolor="#ccffcc" |align="left"|{{fbu|17|ENG}} |3||3||0||0||7||0||+7||'''9''' |- bgcolor="#ccffcc" |align="left"|{{fbu|17|NED}} |3||2||0||1||7||2||+5||'''6''' |- bgcolor="#ffcccc" |align="left"|''{{fbu|17|BIH}}'' |3||1||0||2||1||5||−4||'''3''' |- bgcolor="#ffcccc" |align="left"|{{fbu|17|LAT}} |3||0||0||3||1||9||−8||'''0''' |} {{footballbox collapsible |date = 26 October 2011 |time = 14:00 [[UTC+2]] |team1 = {{fbu-rt|17|ENG}} |score = 4 â 0 |result = W |report = [http://www.uefa.com/under17/season=2012/matches/round=2000208/match=2004867/index.html Report] |team2 = {{fbu|17|LAT}} |goals1 = Robinson {{goal|3}}
